segments.text: Smokey the bear, Smokey the bear.
Hello there, folks.
This is Smokey, the forest fire-preventing bear.
Those singing friends of mine, the sons of the pioneers, have a song for you.
But first, how about joining us on a little visit to a big star?
Today, it's a wonderful friend of mine, Roy Rogers.
And here he comes now.
Well, welcome to the ranch, Smokey.
Seems to me that the last time we got together was at Madison Square Garden when I had the rodeo there.
Yes, and you took time out to talk to a lot of boys and girls about forest fire prevention.
I just want to tell you, Roy, how much good your words have helped.
Every day.
More and more boys and girls, and grown-ups too, are enlisting in the battle against forest fires.
Well, that's what it takes, Smokey.
Everyone pitching in to prevent them.
Every year, wildfires burn up millions of our trees, they damage our valuable watersheds, they destroy the food and homes of wildlife, and they desecrate the God-given beauty of our great outdoors.
You know, Smokey, I've thought a great deal about this.
When we're careless with fire, when we let it run wild and become its slave rather than to remain its master, we do ourselves and others a great injustice.
It's really kind of sinful.
If all of us would just think about it in this way, maybe we could have a lot fewer forest fires starting through carelessness.
Thank you, Roy.
Now, here are your singing pals, the sons of the pioneers, with an old favorite, Cowboy Camp Meeting.
And I got the word I know that it's right And have you heard?

I'm gonna ride cowboy camping Ride cowboy camping Ride cowboy camping Ride on the golden range up in the sky Up in the sky, way up in the sky Yes, well ride cowboy camping Yes, sir, way up in the sky Brother Buffalo Bell and Sister Lou is gonna beat our brother like me and you And old Kent Carson, he will too way up in the sky
I recall way up in the sky

Play, cowboy, can't meet you Play, cowboy, can't meet you Play, cowboy, can't meet you Play on the golden harp up in the sky Up in the sky, up in the sky Guess what, cowboy, can't meet you Way up in the sky, cowboy, way up in the sky Way up in the sky, cowboy, can't meet you Way up in the sky Always
Up in the sky.
Well, that's it for now, folks.
Thanks a lot for spending this time with us.
You know, it's your own state forestry department, along with the Forest Service, U.S.
Department of Agriculture, and this station you're listening to that make these get-togethers possible.
Until we say hello there again and pay another little visit to another big star, this is Smokey and his pals, the Sons of the Pioneers, asking you to always remember only you
can prevent forest and range fires.
Smokey the bear, Smokey the bear, prowling and a-growling and a-sniff in the air.
He can find a fire before it starts to flame.
That's why they call him Smokey, that was how he got his name.
Oh
